item.title: 221 - EVPN VXLAN Multi-Site 1
item.description: First, I followed the lab from Nick Carlton’s blog, but I had trouble getting the multi-site setup to work. Then, I found this article on LinkedIn that is detailed and easy to follow: Deploying Cisco VXLAN EVPN Multi-Site.

item.title: 220 - EVPN VXLAN
item.description: VXLAN is extending Layer 2 networks across Layer 3. There are challenges in bringing Layer 2 and Layer 3 networks. BGP EVPN route types help solve these problems: Distributing L2 and L3 Information BGP EVPN advertises both L2 and L3 info in a single control plane.

item.title: OSPF Stub Area
item.description: The goal is to simplify routing information in the network. Config # It’s a router-level configuration. (under router ospf <process_id>) Within the same area, different routers can have mixed and matched area types.

item.title: 215 - multi-AS MPLS
item.description: I set up a lab (topology only) based on this GNS3 lab. I’m not using that workbook; I built it on my own. I’m using OSPF for the IGP. Key Points:

item.title: ARP PRoxy
item.description: Topology: R2 - SW1 - R1 - SW2 - R3 R2 - R1: 10.1.0.0/16 R3 - R1: 10.1.2.0/24 R2 uses 10.1.1.1 R3 uses 10.1.2.1 Basically, a larger network is needed to reach a smaller network (overlapped) via a router.

item.title: Default Gateway
item.description: This took me a lot of time to troubleshoot, but it’s actually a simple concept I wasn’t aware of. In my lab, we typically use routers as end devices (PCs), and to set up the default gateway, I usually disable routing with the no ip routing command and then use ip default-gateway to setup default gateway.

item.title: Multicast
item.description: PIM Setup # Router Configuration: Enable multicast functionality on the router: ip multicast-routing Enable PIM on interfaces that will handle multicast traffic. You can choose between sparse mode and dense mode.

item.title: 25 - Setup DMVPN
item.description: DMVPN # Hub and spoke topology Uses multiple GRE tunnels Requirement: All routers are accessible to each other, typically over the internet Allows for easy addition of new spokes without reconfiguring the hub Useful for sites (spoke) with changing public IP addresses DMVPN Phases:

item.title: 24 - Setup MPLS VPN
item.description: MPLS # Label-based forwarding: Labels are used for packet transfer across the network This allows for more efficient packet switching and enables advanced services. Routing vs. Forwarding: The routing table determines the path, but LDP (Label Distribution Protocol) creates the label-switched path.
